Section 5.1 Sequences.question 1: Find the formula for the nth term of the sequence: an = 1 + (-1)^n, for n ≥ 1.

Section 5.1 Sequences.question 2: Find the formula for the nth term of the sequence: an = n^2 - 1, for n ≥ 1.

Section 5.1 Sequences.question 3: Find the formula for the nth term of the sequence: a1 = 1 and an = an-1 + n, for n ≥ 2.

Section 5.1 Sequences.question 4: Find the formula for the nth term of the sequence: a1 = 1, a2 = 1 and an+2 = an + an+1, for n ≥ 1.

Section 5.1 Sequences.question 5: Find the explicit formula for the nth term of the sequence: a1 = 1 and an = an-1 + n, for n ≥ 2.

Section 5.1 Sequences.question 6: Find a formula for the nth term of an arithmetic sequence with a1 = 1, such that an+1 - an = 17, for n ≥ 1.

Section 5.1 Sequences.question 7: Find a formula for the nth term of an arithmetic sequence with a1 = -3, such that an+1 - an = 4, for n ≥ 1.

Section 5.1 Sequences.question 8: Find a formula for the nth term of a geometric sequence with a1 = 1, such that an+1 / an = 10, for n ≥ 1.

Section 5.1 Sequences.question 9: Find a formula for the nth term of a geometric sequence with a1 = 3, such that an+1 / an = 1/10, for n ≥ 1.

Section 5.1 Sequences.question 10: Find an explicit formula for the nth term of the sequence whose first several terms are {0,3,8,15,24,35,48,63,80,99,…}. (Hint: First add one to each term.)

Section 5.1 Sequences.question 11: Find an explicit formula for the nth term of the sequence satisfying a1=0 and an=2an−1+1 for n≥2.

Section 5.1 Sequences.question 12: Find a formula for the general term an of the following sequence: {1,0,−1,0,1,0,−1,0,…}. (Hint: Find where sinx takes these values)

Section 5.1 Sequences.question 13: Find a formula for the general term an of the following sequence: {1,−1/3,1/5,−1/7,…}.

Section 5.1 Sequences.question 14: Find a function f(n) that identifies the nth term an of the following recursively defined sequence: a1=1 and an+1=−an for n≥1.

Section 5.1 Sequences.question 15: Find a function f(n) that identifies the nth term an of the following recursively defined sequence: a1=2 and an+1=2an for n≥1.

Section 5.1 Sequences.question 16: Find a function f(n) that identifies the nth term an of the following recursively defined sequence: a1=1 and an+1=(n+1)an for n≥1.

Section 5.1 Sequences.question 17: Find a function f(n) that identifies the nth term an of the following recursively defined sequence: a1=2 and an+1=(n+1)an/2 for n≥1.

Section 5.1 Sequences.question 18: Find a function f(n) that identifies the nth term an of the following recursively defined sequence: a1=1 and an+1=an/2n for n≥1.

Section 5.1 Sequences.question 19: Plot the first N terms of the sequence: a1=1, a2=2, and for n≥2, an=12(an−1+an−2); N=30. State whether the graphical evidence suggests that the sequence converges or diverges.

Section 5.1 Sequences.question 20: Plot the first N terms of the sequence: a1=1, a2=2, a3=3 and for n≥4, an=13(an−1+an−2+an−3); N=30. State whether the graphical evidence suggests that the sequence converges or diverges.

Section 5.1 Sequences.question 21: Plot the first N terms of the sequence: a1=1, a2=2, and for n≥3, an=an−1an−2−−−−−−−√; N=30. State whether the graphical evidence suggests that the sequence converges or diverges.

Section 5.1 Sequences.question 22: Plot the first N terms of the sequence: a1=1, a2=2, a3=3, and for n≥4, an=an−1an−2an−3−−−−−−−−−−−√; N=30. State whether the graphical evidence suggests that the sequence converges or diverges.

Section 5.1 Sequences.question 27: Find the limit of the sequence: n22n

Section 5.1 Sequences.question 28: Find the limit of the sequence: (n−1)2(n+1)2

Section 5.1 Sequences.question 29: Find the limit of the sequence: n√n+1√

Section 5.1 Sequences.question 30: Find the limit of the sequence: n1/n

Section 5.1 Sequences.question 31: For the sequence n/2n, n≥2, determine if it is bounded and eventually monotone.

Section 5.1 Sequences.question 32: For the sequence ln(1+1n), determine if it is bounded and eventually monotone.

Section 5.1 Sequences.question 33: For the sequence sinn, determine if it is bounded and eventually monotone.

Section 5.1 Sequences.question 34: For the sequence cos(n2), determine if it is bounded and eventually monotone.

Section 5.1 Sequences.question 35: For the sequence n1/n, n≥3, determine if it is bounded and eventually monotone.

Section 5.1 Sequences.question 61: A student takes out a college loan of $10,000 at an annual percentage rate of 6%, compounded monthly. If the student makes payments of $100 per month, how much does the student owe after 12 months? After how many months will the loan be paid off?
Section 5.1 Sequences.sequence: Amount owed on the college loan after n months

Section 5.1 Sequences.question 62: Consider a series combining geometric growth and arithmetic decrease. Let a1=1. Fix a>1 and 0<b<a. Set an+1=a.an−b. Find a formula for an+1 in terms of an, a, and b and a relationship between a and b such that an converges.
Section 5.1 Sequences.sequence: Sequence an combining geometric growth and arithmetic decrease

Section 5.1 Sequences.question 63: The binary representation x=0.b1b2b3... of a number x between 0 and 1 can be defined as follows. Let b1=0 if x<1/2 and b1=1 if 1/2≤x<1. Let x1=2x−b1. Let b2=0 if x1<1/2 and b2=1 if 1/2≤x<1. Let x2=2x1−b2 and in general, xn=2xn−1−bn and bn−1=0 if xn<1/2 and bn−1=1 if 1/2≤xn<1. Find the binary expansion of 1/3.

Section 5.1 Sequences.question 64: To find an approximation for π, set a0=2+1−−−−√, a1=2+a0−−−−−√, and, in general, an+1=2+an−−−−−√. Finally, set pn=3.2n2−an−−−−−√. Find the first ten terms of pn and compare the values to π.
Section 5.1 Sequences.sequence: Approximation of π using the sequence pn

an=n

an=1/n

an=(-1)^n

Sn=1−1/n,
n≥2

Sn=n(n+1)/2,
n≥1

n≥2

n≥1

seqSection 5.2 Infinite Series.question 79:
For each of the following series, use the sequence of partial sums to determine whether the series converges or diverges.
∑n=1∞n/(n+2)

seqSection 5.2 Infinite Series.question 80:

∑n=1∞(1-(-1)^n)

∑n=1∞1/((n+1)(n+2))

seqSection 5.2 Infinite Series.question 82:

∑n=1∞1/(2n+1)

seqSection 5.2 Infinite Series.question 83:
Suppose that ∑n=1∞an=1, that ∑n=1∞bn=−1, that a1=2, and b1=−3. Find the sum of the indicated series.
∑n=1∞(an+bn)

seqSection 5.2 Infinite Series.question 84:
Suppose that ∑n=1∞an=1, that ∑n=1∞bn=−1, that a1=2, and b1=−3. Find the sum of the indicated series.

∑n=1∞(3an+1-4bn+1)

limn→∞an=0 but the series ∑n=1∞an diverges.

seqSection 5.2 Infinite Series.question 99:
The Taylor series centered at x=0 for a function f has the given interval of convergence. Determine whether each statement is true or false.

The radius of convergence is 2.
seqSection 5.2 Infinite Series.sequence: Analysis of the radius of convergence for a Taylor series

seqSection 5.2 Infinite Series.question 100:
The Taylor series centered at x=0 for a function f has the given interval of convergence. Determine whether each statement is true or false.

The series converges for all x.
seqSection 5.2 Infinite Series.sequence: Analysis of the interval of convergence for a Taylor series

seqSection 5.2 Infinite Series.question 101:
The Taylor series centered at x=0 for a function f has the given interval of convergence. Determine whether each statement is true or false.

The series converges only at x=0.
seqSection 5.2 Infinite Series.sequence: Analysis of the interval of convergence for a Taylor series

seqSection 5.2 Infinite Series.question 102:
The Taylor series centered at x=0 for a function f has the given interval of convergence. Determine whether each statement is true or false.

The interval of convergence is (−2,2).
seqSection 5.2 Infinite Series.sequence: Analysis of the interval of convergence for a Taylor series

seqSection 5.2 Infinite Series.question 127: [T] Suppose that the amount of a drug in a patient’s system diminishes by a multiplicative factor r < 1 each hour. Suppose that a new dose is administered every N hours. Find an expression that gives the amount A(n) in the patient’s system after n hours for each n in terms of the dosage d and the ratio r. (Hint: Write n = mN + k, where 0 ≤ k < N, and sum over values from the different doses administered.)
seqSection 5.2 Infinite Series.sequence: Amount of drug in patient's system after n hours

seqSection 5.2 Infinite Series.question 128: [T] A certain drug is effective for an average patient only if there is at least 1 mg per kg in the patient’s system, while it is safe only if there is at most 2 mg per kg in an average patient’s system. Suppose that the amount in a patient’s system diminishes by a multiplicative factor of 0.9 each hour after a dose is administered. Find the maximum interval N of hours between doses, and corresponding dose range d (in mg/kg) for this N that will enable use of the drug to be both safe and effective in the long term.
seqSection 5.2 Infinite Series.sequence: Dose regimen for safe and effective use of a drug

seqSection 5.2 Infinite Series.question 129: Suppose that an ≥ 0 is a sequence of numbers. Explain why the sequence of partial sums of an is increasing.

seqSection 5.2 Infinite Series.question 130: [T] Suppose that an is a sequence of positive numbers and the sequence Sn of partial sums of an is bounded above. Explain why ∑n=1∞an converges. Does the conclusion remain true if we remove the hypothesis an ≥ 0?

Suppose a scooter can travel 100
 km on a full tank of fuel. Assuming that fuel can be transferred from one scooter to another but can only be carried in the tank, present a procedure that will enable one of the scooters to travel 100HN
 km, where HN=1+1/2+⋯+1/N.

Section 5.4 Comparison Tests.question 213: Use the limit comparison test to determine whether the following series converge or diverge. ∑∞n=11e(1.1)n−3n

Section 5.4 Comparison Tests.question 214: Use the limit comparison test to determine whether the following series converge or diverge. ∑∞n=11e(1.01)n−3n

Section 5.4 Comparison Tests.question 215: Use the limit comparison test to determine whether the following series converge or diverge. ∑∞n=11n1+1/n

Section 5.4 Comparison Tests.question 216: Use the limit comparison test to determine whether the following series converge or diverge. ∑∞n=1121+1/nn1+1/n

Section 5.4 Comparison Tests.question 217: Use the limit comparison test to determine whether the following series converge or diverge. ∑∞n=1(1n−sin(1n))

Section 5.4 Comparison Tests.question 218: Use the limit comparison test to determine whether the following series converge or diverge. ∑∞n=1(1−cos(1n))

Section 5.4 Comparison Tests.question 219: Use the limit comparison test to determine whether the following series converge or diverge. ∑∞n=11n(π2−tan−1n)

Section 5.4 Comparison Tests.question 220:
Use the limit comparison test to determine whether the following series converge or diverge. ∑∞n=1(1−1n)n.n
 (Hint: (1−1n)n→1/e.)

Section 5.4 Comparison Tests.question 221:
Use the limit comparison test to determine whether the following series converge or diverge. ∑∞n=1(1−e−1/n)
 (Hint: 1/e≈(1−1/n)n,
 so 1−e−1/n≈1/n.)

Section 5.4 Comparison Tests.question 222:
Use the limit comparison test to determine whether the following series converge or diverge. Does ∑∞n=21(lnn)p
 converge if p
 is large enough? If so, for which p?

Section 5.4 Comparison Tests.question 223:
Use the limit comparison test to determine whether the following series converge or diverge. Does ∑∞n=1((lnn)n)p
 converge if p
 is large enough? If so, for which p?

Section 5.4 Comparison Tests.question 224:
Use the limit comparison test to determine for which p
 does the series ∑∞n=12pn/3n
 converge?

Section 5.4 Comparison Tests.question 225:
Use the limit comparison test to determine for which p>0
 does the series ∑∞n=1np2n
 converge?

Section 5.4 Comparison Tests.question 226:
Use the limit comparison test to determine for which r>0
 does the series ∑∞n=1rn22n
 converge?

Section 5.4 Comparison Tests.question 227:
Use the limit comparison test to determine for which r>0
 does the series ∑∞n=12nrn2
 converge?

Section 5.4 Comparison Tests.question 228:
Use the limit comparison test to determine all values of p
 and q
 such that the series ∑∞n=1np(n!)q
 converges.

Section 5.4 Comparison Tests.question 229:
Determine whether the series ∑∞n=1sin2(nr/2)n
 converges or diverges. Explain.

Section 5.4 Comparison Tests.question 240: Prove that if ∑bn converges, then ∑an converges, given that an/bn→0 in the comparison test, where an≥0 and bn≥0.

Section 5.4 Comparison Tests.question 241: What is the largest possible value of x=∑n=1∞bn/2n, where bn is an infinite sequence of zeros and ones?

Section 5.4 Comparison Tests.question 242: What is the largest possible value of x=∑n=1∞dn/10n, where dn is an infinite sequence of digits (0-9) that converges?

Section 5.4 Comparison Tests.question 243: Explain why, if x>1/2, then x cannot be written x=∑n=2∞bn2n (bn=0 or 1, b1=0).

Section 5.4 Comparison Tests.question 244: Evelyn has a perfect balancing scale, an unlimited number of 1-kg weights, and one each of 1/2-kg, 1/4-kg, 1/8-kg, and so on weights. Can she weigh a meteorite of unspecified origin to arbitrary precision using these weights? What does this have to do with infinite series?
